articles.headline: California Sued Over Diversion of Money From National Mortgage Settlement
articles.snippet: Three nonprofit groups want Gov. Jerry Brown to return $369 million used to pay down state debt, rather than help struggling homeowners.
articles.abstract: Three nonprofit groups want Gov. Jerry Brown to return $369 million used to pay down state debt, rather than help struggling homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three nonprofit groups offering homeowner counseling sued Gov. Jerry Brown of California on Friday, demanding the state replace $369 million that had been earmarked to help troubled borrowers but was used instead to pay down the state’s debt.

articles.headline: China’s Online Goliaths Prepare Public Offerings in U.S.
articles.snippet: The Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba is said to be planning to follow the social network Weibo into filing for an I.P.O. in New York, rather than in Hong Kong.
articles.abstract: The Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba is said to be planning to follow the social network Weibo into filing for an I.P.O. in New York, rather than in Hong Kong.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | The Chinese Internet industry is coming of age, as some of its biggest players prepare to start new chapters as publicly traded companies — in the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Dragnet at Dewey & LeBoeuf Snares a Minnow
articles.snippet: Zachary Warren, a low-level employee at the once-giant law firm, was the unwitting target of an increasingly common prosecutorial tactic called parallel construction.
articles.abstract: Zachary Warren, a low-level employee at the once-giant law firm, was the unwitting target of an increasingly common prosecutorial tactic called parallel construction.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You’ve been indicted,” an assistant Manhattan district attorney, Peirce Moser, told Zachary Warren, a 29-year-old magna cum laude graduate of Georgetown Law School with a prestigious clerkship on the Federal Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Memphis.

articles.headline: Radar Suggests Jet Shifted Path More Than Once
articles.snippet: A military radar track appeared to show that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 climbed to 45,000 feet after disappearing from civilian radar and altered its course as if still under a pilot’s command.
articles.abstract: A military radar track appeared to show that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 climbed to 45,000 feet after disappearing from civilian radar and altered its course as if still under a pilot’s command.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 experienced significant changes in altitude after it lost contact with ground control, and altered its course more than once as if still under the command of a pilot, American officials and others familiar with the investigation said Friday.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: U.S. to Cede Its Oversight of Addresses on Internet
articles.snippet: An international group, not yet determined, will take over the task of assigning names and numbers for Internet addresses.
articles.abstract: An international group, not yet determined, will take over the task of assigning names and numbers for Internet addresses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States will give up its role overseeing the system of Web addresses and domain names that form the basic plumbing of the Internet, turning it over in 2015 to an international group whose structure and administration will be determined over the next year, government officials said on Friday.

articles.headline: A Store With Media in Mind
articles.snippet: At Story, a Manhattan boutique, products change often and reflect specific themes.
articles.abstract: At Story, a Manhattan boutique, products change often and reflect specific themes.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a Manhattan boutique called Story, shoppers can buy delicate lingerie or intricately decorated chocolate, scented candles or underwear made by a Swedish company called Bread & Boxers.

articles.headline: Senate Balks at Obama Pick for Surgeon General
articles.snippet: The White House is considering putting off a Senate vote on Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, who has come under criticism from the National Rifle Association, or withdrawing the nomination altogether.
articles.abstract: The White House is considering putting off a Senate vote on Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, who has come under criticism from the National Rifle Association, or withdrawing the nomination altogether.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing a possible defeat in the Senate, the White House is considering delaying a vote on President Obama’s choice for surgeon general or withdrawing the nomination altogether, an acknowledgment of its fraying relationship with Senate Democrats.

articles.headline: Malaysia Officials Open Criminal Inquiry Into Missing Jet
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Najib Razak said in a news conference that data indicated that someone took action to change the course of the plane, which traveled for seven hours after it lost contact with ground control.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Najib Razak said in a news conference that data indicated that someone took action to change the course of the plane, which traveled for seven hours after it lost contact with ground control.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The search for Flight 370 turned into a criminal investigation on Saturday, after Malaysia declared that the plane had been deliberately diverted and then flown for as long as seven hours toward an unknown point far from its scheduled route of Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: As Scandal Unfolds, G.M. Calls In the Lawyers
articles.snippet: In its recall crisis, General Motors is doing what many scandal-plagued companies do. It’s trying to manage the problem with an internal investigation.
articles.abstract: In its recall crisis, General Motors is doing what many scandal-plagued companies do. It’s trying to manage the problem with an internal investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last summer, a lawyer named Lance Cooper sensed that his long battle with General Motors was coming to an end.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Barry Meier

articles.headline: A Loan Fraud War That’s Short on Combat
articles.snippet: The Justice Department put investigations of mortgage crime on the back burner.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department put investigations of mortgage crime on the back burner.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the years since the financial crisis of 2008, the Justice Department has been regularly questioned about a lack of criminal prosecutions related to the mortgage mess.

articles.headline: Obama Factor Adds to Fears of Democrats
articles.snippet: The president’s sinking ratings, a loss in a House election in Florida and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law are complicating matters.
articles.abstract: The president’s sinking ratings, a loss in a House election in Florida and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law are complicating matters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats are becoming increasingly alarmed about their midterm election fortunes amid President Obama’s sinking approval ratings, a loss in a special House election in Florida last week, and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Russia Seizes Gas Plant Near Crimea Border, Ukraine Says
articles.snippet: On the eve of a secession referendum in Crimea, Russian forces took a natural gas terminal while Western officials prepared sanctions for Moscow.
articles.abstract: On the eve of a secession referendum in Crimea, Russian forces took a natural gas terminal while Western officials prepared sanctions for Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — Tensions mounted on the eve of a secession referendum here in Crimea as helicopter-borne Russian forces made a provocative incursion just outside the peninsula’s regional border to seize a natural gas terminal, while American and European officials prepared sanctions to impose on Moscow as early as Monday.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn, Peter Baker and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Income Gap, Meet the Longevity Gap
articles.snippet: Two counties, separated by fortune and 350 miles, demonstrate the widening divide in life expectancy between affluent and struggling areas of the United States.
articles.abstract: Two counties, separated by fortune and 350 miles, demonstrate the widening divide in life expectancy between affluent and struggling areas of the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fairfax County, Va., and McDowell County, W.Va., are separated by 350 miles, about a half-day’s drive. Traveling west from Fairfax County, the gated communities and bland architecture of military contractors give way to exurbs, then to farmland and eventually to McDowell’s coal mines and the forested slopes of the Appalachians. Perhaps the greatest distance between the two counties is this: Fairfax is a place of the haves, and McDowell of the have-nots. Just outside of Washington, fat government contracts and a growing technology sector buoy the median household income in Fairfax County up to $107,000, one of the highest in the nation. McDowell, with the decline of coal, has little in the way of industry. Unemployment is high. Drug abuse is rampant. Median household income is about one-fifth that of Fairfax.

articles.headline: Timing of Report by Flight’s Pilot Focuses Inquiry
articles.snippet: The pilot did not mention any trouble, a senior Malaysian official said, reinforcing theories that one or both of the pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane.
articles.abstract: The pilot did not mention any trouble, a senior Malaysian official said, reinforcing theories that one or both of the pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — A signaling system was disabled on the missing Malaysia Airlines jet before a pilot spoke to air traffic control without mentioning any trouble, a senior Malaysian official said Sunday, reinforcing theories that one or both of the pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane and adding urgency to the investigation of their pasts and possible motivations.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: In China, Shaking Up Currency’s Strength
articles.snippet: Recent developments suggest that the renminbi’s day-to-day strengthening is no longer the certainty it once appeared to be.
articles.abstract: Recent developments suggest that the renminbi’s day-to-day strengthening is no longer the certainty it once appeared to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — One of the surest bets on China is starting to look a bit shaky.

articles.headline: Army General Reaches Deal on Sex Counts
articles.snippet: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair is expected to plead guilty to sharply reduced charges in the military’s most closely watched sexual assault case.
articles.abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair is expected to plead guilty to sharply reduced charges in the military’s most closely watched sexual assault case.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The senior Army officer prosecuted in the military’s most closely watched sexual assault case, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, has agreed to plead guilty to sharply reduced charges, including that he disobeyed a commander’s order, misused his government charge card and mistreated his former mistress, a captain.

articles.headline: Undercover TV Reports on School Security Raise Ethical Questions
articles.snippet: School shootings have prompted efforts by news organizations in recent months to assess the effectiveness of safety measures, but some of these reports have gone disturbingly wrong.
articles.abstract: School shootings have prompted efforts by news organizations in recent months to assess the effectiveness of safety measures, but some of these reports have gone disturbingly wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: The three news reports followed the same format: Television reporters walked into schools with hidden cameras, under the premise of testing the security measures. Each time, the anchors provided a sobering assessment of the findings.

articles.headline: A New Model for Music: Big Bands, Big Brands
articles.snippet: At the South by Southwest festival this year, historically a place of artistic idiosyncrasy, corporate logos were everywhere.
articles.abstract: At the South by Southwest festival this year, historically a place of artistic idiosyncrasy, corporate logos were everywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: I like Doritos as much as the next guy. More, probably. And I admire Lady Gaga for her handcrafted rise to the top of pop culture. In Austin last week, the salty, cheesy wonder of Doritos was brought to you by the sweet, uplifting allure of Lady Gaga. Or was it the other way around?

articles.headline: Start-Ups Aim to Conquer Space Market
articles.snippet: The start-up Planet Labs is challenging the giants of the space industry by producing dozens of small satellites that are cheaper and quicker to build than traditional satellites.
articles.abstract: The start-up Planet Labs is challenging the giants of the space industry by producing dozens of small satellites that are cheaper and quicker to build than traditional satellites.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was party time at the Planet Labs satellite factory, in an unkempt office in the trendy South of Market neighborhood here.
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: West’s Drought and Growth Intensify Conflict Over Water Rights
articles.snippet: The explosive growth of cities is raising the stakes for farmers and industry amid a series of fierce legal and political battles over water.
articles.abstract: The explosive growth of cities is raising the stakes for farmers and industry amid a series of fierce legal and political battles over water.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMFORD, Tex. — Across the parched American West, the long drought has set off a series of fierce legal and political battles over who controls an increasingly dear treasure — water.

articles.headline: Unskilled and Destitute Are Hiring Targets for Fukushima Cleanup
articles.snippet: The operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant has left the complex cleanup to a poorly trained work force that has made some dangerous missteps.
articles.abstract: The operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant has left the complex cleanup to a poorly trained work force that has made some dangerous missteps.
articles.lead_paragraph: NARAHA, Japan — “Out of work? Nowhere to live? Nowhere to go? Nothing to eat?” the online ad reads. “Come to Fukushima.”

articles.headline: Low-Wage Workers Are Finding Poverty Harder to Escape
articles.snippet: For those at the low end of the hourly wage scale, even meeting basic household needs can be a stretch, and roads out of poverty are scarce.
articles.abstract: For those at the low end of the hourly wage scale, even meeting basic household needs can be a stretch, and roads out of poverty are scarce.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — At 7 in the morning, they are already lined up — poultry plant workers, housekeepers, discount store clerks — to ask for help paying their heating bills or feeding their families.

articles.headline: Global Crises Put Obama’s Strategy of Caution to the Test
articles.snippet: Turmoil in Ukraine and Syria is challenging President Obama’s attempts to change the way the United States deals with its overseas adversaries.
articles.abstract: Turmoil in Ukraine and Syria is challenging President Obama’s attempts to change the way the United States deals with its overseas adversaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For five years, President Obama has consciously recast how America engages with the world’s toughest customers. But with Russia poised to annex Crimea after Sunday’s referendum, with a mounting threat to the rest of Ukraine and with the carnage in Syria accelerating, Mr. Obama’s strategy is now under greater stress than at any time in his presidency.

articles.headline: Lost Jet’s Path Seen as Altered via Computer
articles.snippet: The first turn that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its route was entered into a computer system, most likely by someone in the plane’s cockpit, American officials said.
articles.abstract: The first turn that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its route was entered into a computer system, most likely by someone in the plane’s cockpit, American officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first turn to the west that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its planned flight path from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing was carried out through a computer system that was most likely programmed by someone in the plane’s cockpit who was knowledgeable about airplane systems, according to senior American officials.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Putative Bitcoin Founder Categorically Denies It
articles.snippet: Dorian Nakamoto appeared to be laying the groundwork for a lawsuit against Newsweek, saying its article had harmed him. He stopped short of saying he would sue.
articles.abstract: Dorian Nakamoto appeared to be laying the groundwork for a lawsuit against Newsweek, saying its article had harmed him. He stopped short of saying he would sue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Around 10 days after being identified by Newsweek magazine as the mysterious creator of the digital currency Bitcoin, Dorian Nakamoto, a 64-year-old semi-employed engineer, has hired a lawyer and issued a statement unconditionally denying that he had any involvement in Bitcoin.

articles.headline: Putin Recognizes Crimea Secession, Defying the West
articles.snippet: The Kremlin announced that President Vladimir V. Putin would address both houses of the Russian Parliament on Tuesday, when many expect him to endorse annexation.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin announced that President Vladimir V. Putin would address both houses of the Russian Parliament on Tuesday, when many expect him to endorse annexation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signed a decree on Monday formally recognizing Crimea as a “sovereign and independent state,” laying the groundwork for annexation and defying the United States and Europe just hours after they imposed their first financial sanctions against Moscow since the crisis in Ukraine began.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Peter Baker
